articles.headline: Stocks Fall to End a Bad Week, and a Boom Begins to Look Shaky
articles.snippet: U.S. stocks have ended their worst week since February 2016, as investors worried about rising interest rates after a long market boom.
articles.abstract: U.S. stocks have ended their worst week since February 2016, as investors worried about rising interest rates after a long market boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors have spent much of the last year shrugging off geopolitical and economic risks, from the threat of nuclear conflict with North Korea to a potential trade war with China. Instead, they have focused on the strength of the United States economy, driven by banner corporate profits and President Trump’s push to lower taxes and reduce regulation.

articles.headline: Leading Private Equity Firm Accused of Misusing Funds
articles.snippet: The Abraaj Group, a top investor in the developing world, faces questions from the World Bank and other investors.
articles.abstract: The Abraaj Group, a top investor in the developing world, faces questions from the World Bank and other investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Abraaj Group has  a reputation as one of the developing world’s largest and most influential investors. The private equity firm, based in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, manages nearly $14 billion for institutions including development agencies in the United States, Britain and France.

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Shackles Wells Fargo After Fraud Scandal
articles.snippet: After a scandal involving fraudulent accounts, the central bank restricted the growth of Wells Fargo, which said it would replace four board members.
articles.abstract: After a scandal involving fraudulent accounts, the central bank restricted the growth of Wells Fargo, which said it would replace four board members.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve on Friday imposed unusually harsh penalties on Wells Fargo, punishing it for years of misconduct and barring it from future growth until the bank fixes its problems.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Binyamin Appelbaum and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Payday Rules Relax on Trump’s Watch After Lobbying by Lenders
articles.snippet: The industry has gone from villain to victor, the result of a lobbying campaign that has culminated in a far friendlier approach by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
articles.abstract: The industry has gone from villain to victor, the result of a lobbying campaign that has culminated in a far friendlier approach by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In mid-April, hundreds of members of the payday lending industry will head to Florida for their annual retreat featuring golf and networking at a plush resort just outside Miami. The resort just happens to be the Trump National Doral Golf Club.

articles.headline: Aiming at China’s Armpits: When Foreign Brands Misfire
articles.snippet: Companies like Starbucks and KFC have prospered in China, but cultural differences and other factors have also led to notable failures.
articles.abstract: Companies like Starbucks and KFC have prospered in China, but cultural differences and other factors have also led to notable failures.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Unilever brought its Rexona deodorant to China a decade ago, dreaming of a market with 2.6 billion armpits.

articles.headline: How Trump’s Allies Fanned an Ember of Controversy Into Flames of Outrage
articles.snippet: A memo by House Republicans didn’t live up to its billing, but the tactics used to stoke doubts about law enforcement could have a lingering impact on the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: A memo by House Republicans didn’t live up to its billing, but the tactics used to stoke doubts about law enforcement could have a lingering impact on the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The release of the memo mattered less than #releasethememo.

articles.headline: What We Talk About When We Talk About Pay Inequity
articles.snippet: Five women of different backgrounds, professions and ages convened for dinner to discuss one thing they all have in common: the gender wage gap.
articles.abstract: Five women of different backgrounds, professions and ages convened for dinner to discuss one thing they all have in common: the gender wage gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in her career, Jewelle Bickford, now a partner at Evercore Wealth Management, worked at a global bank in New York with a male colleague who was on his best behavior during the first half of the day, she said, but during and after lunch, his work ethic devolved. “When he came back, you would walk by his office, and he would have his head down,” Ms. Bickford said. “And you knew he had had quite a few drinks.”

articles.headline: ‘They Can’t Wait to Vote’: Energized Democrats Target Dominant G.O.P. in Statehouses
articles.snippet: Republicans have dominated state governments for almost a decade, but Democrats are exploiting President Trump’s unpopularity in an effort to make inroads in 2018.
articles.abstract: Republicans have dominated state governments for almost a decade, but Democrats are exploiting President Trump’s unpopularity in an effort to make inroads in 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Pa. — For Republicans in the states, the political warning signs keep mounting: In Virginia, it was an electoral shellacking that nearly snapped their 20-year grip on the State House. In Wisconsin, it was a midwinter rout in a special election for the State Senate, fought in a conservative district.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Secret Alliance: Israel Carries Out Airstrikes in Egypt, With Cairo’s O.K.
articles.snippet: Unmarked Israeli aircraft have been pounding Islamist militants in the North Sinai. Israel’s role has been kept secret to prevent a backlash in Egypt.
articles.abstract: Unmarked Israeli aircraft have been pounding Islamist militants in the North Sinai. Israel’s role has been kept secret to prevent a backlash in Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: The jihadists in Egypt’s Northern Sinai had killed hundreds of soldiers and police officers, pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, briefly seized a major town and begun setting up armed checkpoints to claim territory. In late 2015, they brought down a Russian passenger jet.

articles.headline: Trump’s Unparalleled War on a Pillar of Society: Law Enforcement
articles.snippet: President Trump has raised fears that he is tearing at the credibility of some of the most important institutions in American life to save himself.
articles.abstract: President Trump has raised fears that he is tearing at the credibility of some of the most important institutions in American life to save himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days before the 2016 election, Donald J. Trump expressed “great respect” for the “courage” of the F.B.I. and Justice Department for reopening the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server. Sixteen months later, he has changed his mind.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Benner and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Thousands of ISIS Fighters Flee in Syria, Many to Fight Another Day
articles.snippet: As some militants go into hiding and others slip into Turkey, the flow risks tarnishing American declarations that the Islamic State has been largely defeated.
articles.abstract: As some militants go into hiding and others slip into Turkey, the flow risks tarnishing American declarations that the Islamic State has been largely defeated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thousands of Islamic State foreign fighters and family members have escaped the American-led military campaign in eastern Syria, according to new classified American and other Western military and intelligence assessments, a flow that threatens to tarnish American declarations that the militant group has been largely defeated.

articles.headline: Labor Dept. Plan Could Let the Boss Pocket the Tip
articles.snippet: A move to allow restaurants and other employers to impose tip sharing on workers, and in some cases keep the money, is under fire from labor groups.
articles.abstract: A move to allow restaurants and other employers to impose tip sharing on workers, and in some cases keep the money, is under fire from labor groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is moving to give restaurants and other employers more control over workers’ tips. But critics have denounced the plan as legalizing wage theft and accuse the administration of suppressing evidence that lends credence to the charge.

articles.headline: Advertisers Eschew Politics for Humor in Super Bowl Commercials
articles.snippet: This year’s Super Bowl ads were more humorous than political. But Ram was criticized for using a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a commercial for its truck.
articles.abstract: This year’s Super Bowl ads were more humorous than political. But Ram was criticized for using a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a commercial for its truck.
articles.lead_paragraph: • Last year’s Super Bowl featured several ads that were political in nature. This year, companies focused more on humor and nostalgia.

articles.headline: Amazon Asked for Patience. Remarkably, Wall Street Complied.
articles.snippet: The retailer’s stock is soaring, but it wasn’t always that way. The company had lean years in which it told investors to have faith in its long-term strategy.
articles.abstract: The retailer’s stock is soaring, but it wasn’t always that way. The company had lean years in which it told investors to have faith in its long-term strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allen Gillespie is one lonely stock analyst.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Powell Takes Over as Fed Chief as Economy Starts to Show Strain
articles.snippet: Jerome H. Powell, the new Federal Reserve chairman, is a lawyer in a role performed mostly by economists. Friends say he is up to the challenge.
articles.abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the new Federal Reserve chairman, is a lawyer in a role performed mostly by economists. Friends say he is up to the challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jerome H. Powell was sworn in on Monday as the Federal Reserve’s 16th chairman, stepping into his new role as a half-decade of economic tranquillity is beginning to show some signs of strain.

articles.headline: How Wells Fargo and Federal Reserve Struck Deal to Hold Bank’s Board Accountable
articles.snippet: The landmark settlement between Wells Fargo and the Fed shows regulators’ new emphasis on making board members responsible for their institutions’ conduct.
articles.abstract: The landmark settlement between Wells Fargo and the Fed shows regulators’ new emphasis on making board members responsible for their institutions’ conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Thursday evening in mid-January, a group of top Wells Fargo executives sat down for dinner in an upscale surf-and-turf restaurant near the White House. At nearby tables, power brokers ate seafood on ice and sipped cocktails out of copper mugs.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Binyamin Appelbaum and David Enrich

articles.headline: With a Monday Vote Expected, Democrats Press to Release Their Own Memo
articles.snippet: As some Republicans backed away from President Trump’s claim that a new memo vindicates him in the Russia inquiry, Democrats sought the release of their own classified rebuttal.
articles.abstract: As some Republicans backed away from President Trump’s claim that a new memo vindicates him in the Russia inquiry, Democrats sought the release of their own classified rebuttal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee backed away on Sunday from President Trump’s claim that a newly released memo vindicates him in the Russia investigation, Democrats pressed for the release of their own classified rebuttal, with a vote expected on Monday on whether to make it public.

articles.headline: To Counter Russia, U.S. Signals Nuclear Arms Are Back in a Big Way
articles.snippet: A new nuclear policy issued by the Trump administration, which vows to counter a rush by the Russians to modernize their forces, is touching off a new kind of nuclear arms race.
articles.abstract: A new nuclear policy issued by the Trump administration, which vows to counter a rush by the Russians to modernize their forces, is touching off a new kind of nuclear arms race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A treaty committing the United States and Russia to keep their long-range nuclear arsenals at the lowest levels since early in the Cold War goes into full effect on Monday. When it was signed eight years ago, President Barack Obama expressed hope that it would be a small first step toward deeper reductions, and ultimately a world without nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: How Bell Pottinger, P.R. Firm for Despots and Rogues, Met Its End in South Africa
articles.snippet: The British firm Bell Pottinger, hired by three brothers now caught up in a nationwide corruption scandal, helped drive racial tensions to levels not felt since apartheid.
articles.abstract: The British firm Bell Pottinger, hired by three brothers now caught up in a nationwide corruption scandal, helped drive racial tensions to levels not felt since apartheid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — If an autopsy could have been performed on Bell Pottinger, Britain’s most audacious public relations firm, the cause of death may have been summarized as “acute embarrassment.”

articles.headline: Samsung Heir Freed, to Dismay of South Korea’s Anti-Corruption Campaigners
articles.snippet: The judgment in favor of Lee Jae-yong deals a setback to prosecutors who hoped the original sentence would send a warning to the country’s powerful business tycoons.
articles.abstract: The judgment in favor of Lee Jae-yong deals a setback to prosecutors who hoped the original sentence would send a warning to the country’s powerful business tycoons.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When Lee Jae-yong, the de facto leader of Samsung, walked free on Monday after spending barely a year in jail, it reaffirmed a pattern South Koreans have fought for decades to break: Business tycoons convicted of corruption here hardly spend any time behind bars.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Committee Votes to Release Democratic Rebuttal to G.O.P. Russia Memo
articles.snippet: The House Intelligence Committee voted to release a Democratic rebuttal to a Republican memo on surveillance abuse, putting its fate in President Trump’s hands.
articles.abstract: The House Intelligence Committee voted to release a Democratic rebuttal to a Republican memo on surveillance abuse, putting its fate in President Trump’s hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Intelligence Committee voted unanimously on Monday to make public a classified Democratic memorandum rebutting Republican claims that the F.B.I. and the Justice Department had abused their powers to wiretap a former Trump campaign official, setting up a possible clash with President Trump.

articles.headline: Dow Jones and S.&P. Slide Again, Dropping by More Than 4%
articles.snippet: Sharp moves in the stock market come as investors digest the growth prospects for the world and look for signs of inflation.
articles.abstract: Sharp moves in the stock market come as investors digest the growth prospects for the world and look for signs of inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the global financial crisis a decade ago, a few simple guidelines have helped investors make sense of the markets.
